ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I really liked the class overall. The modeling assignments were really helpful for me since I didn't have much background in modeling in excel.There needs to be a course like this for students at FES. I thought the pace of the class was a bit slow, but I also have a strong background in much of the course material (beyond the modeling pieces).

I thought the most valuable part of the course was the beginning, when we focused on the equations and techniques used in financially modeling investments in timberland. After that, the material became concrete.I think the course would have been better had we started with the equations and techniques (as we did) and then taken up (sequentially) one, two, or three of Professor Spalding's actual deals that she was involved with. This would have grounded the material much more in the real world and would have made it much more applied. As it was taught, it was often hard to get a feel for the relevance of some of the concepts. It seemed like we spent an inordinate amount of time talking about various types of risks without really fitting an appreciation for those risks into a decision-making framework. I think it would have been better to go step by step through a few investments, through Professor Spalding's eyes, to really get a sense for why decisions were made the way they were.I also want to comment that John Loevner, the TA, made himself very available and was very helpful.
Absolutely excellent course, good materials, and well taught.
1. The course readings were targeted and well-structured. The best part of this course was the instructorâs ability to draw on personal experience and guide class discussion.

Re: Question 4The "pace" of the course was not too slow and in fact quite a bit of material was covered and the instructor did an excellent job communicating the information.However, I do feel that more assignments would have helped students absorb the material and apply lectures to the assignments. More intensity would have helped dive home essential concepts.
5) Would have been neat to take a field trip to see some of the work in action.

In reference to question #2: I found the usefulness of assignments varied greatly. Assignments 1, 2, 3, and the final assignment were very practical and I taught me a lot. Assignments 4 and 5 were less useful because they required a much less in depth/precise analysis.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The homework assignments and final assignment. Some of the class discussions were great, too, and Deborah was very willing to bring in her perspectives from her own work it the ecosystem markets sector.
Again, the beginning part where we focused on the equations and techniques used in valuing forestland.
The breadth of covering many parts of ecosystem and forest finance.
Insights from the instructorâs professional experience provided a great point of discussion for framing conclusions from the course readings.

Examples from the instructor's own work experience in forest finance field was very very eye-opening. Some of the assignments allows one to work with real world data in forest finance. Learning how to build a model was one of the best aspects of this course.
The instructor applied knowledge from her work experience, as well as shared documentation from business deals. this was a great insight.
Practice with financial concepts
Learning about basic finance skills through forestry and ecosystem services.
Lectures and discussions were engaging and interesting

Deborah. She brought not just experience, but a realistic perspective on her experiences, which helped me to understand the lay of the land. She was also an extremely engaging lecturer with organized topical lectures and anecdotes each week.
The pragmatic and realistic approach taken by the professor and use of real world cases to explain how things actually operate in the real world.

Since I am an international student and very interested in mechanisms of payments for ecosystem services, the best aspects of this course was to understand the mechanisms existent in the US.I really liked the lecture and texts related to it.
The real world experience Deborah brought to class, the clear examples she shared from the work, etc.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think that the material was often very abstract and disconnected from application.Perhaps using a handful of actual land deals or property data to work through all of the various components would be better? It's very hard to internalize what some of the components really mean until they are connected to some real transaction or situation. In sum I think a case based class would work very well here.

Things became a bit repetitive at the end; I think it would have been more helpful to walk through 2 deals from start to finish. Some of the discussions about risk were so vague it was hard to think about how you would apply in context/bake them into a model.
It's almost too broad, it would be much better to have two classes to cover more material in more depth.
I would have liked to have a more extensive tutorial on how to build a pro forma and work in excel. The TA was a great resource, but it would have been helpful to have a structured class session.
More assignments/rigor/math/excel
Integrating excel with lectures
None

I felt like there was a sudden jump in the complexity of materials expected in the homework assignments with the last few (eg a huge spreadsheet to analyze and the final project), where the practical material learned in the class didn't necessarily help in understanding how to utilize and implement such tools. (Did not make it to office hours which probably would have helped however). A more gradual build-up or some sort of "how-to" on these would have really helped.
Maybe an additional or substitute assignment that taught another finance skill (in addition to the NPV and LEV calculations we learned early on).
None
It should be given more time to topics related to international forestry.Maybe assignments related to international forestry as well.

I occasionally had difficulty integrating specific market details that were common to lectures (e.g. wetland credits) into a larger understanding of how the economy works/is driven. I think a few slides connecting the micro to the macro in each lecture would be very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
N/A
yes.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: intended for general environmental finance background. I'm not a forester and don't plan on buying timberland necessarily.
It was exactly the topic I'm looking to build more experience in for this program.
Perfect fit, it informs forest mgmt decision making and has made me interested in pursuing finance. Completely turned the program around for me.
My work focuses on land management and agriculture, and this course provided an introduction to conservation finance.

For someone aspiring to be a forest resource manager, this course provides the financial knowledge required to do so. One of the focus on international timber markets makes this course appealing for students who will go on to work in international countries. This course is also beneficial for someone like myself who is interested in other services provided by the forests besides timber.
This is the only course at FES that covers finance. I am not a MF or MFS student but seek background in finance to complement my energy background.
This course provided me with a basic in accounting and finance as it relates to timber and ecosystem services investments and management.
Fulfills a requirement for MF, where I had previous experience in economics, but not so much in finance

I am interested in sustainable working lands, and this course was a very useful introduction to how different land uses are monetized and valued. It also introduced me to issues I wasn't aware of. In the end, the course added, for me, another tool and way of thinking about how to conserve land.
This course is essential to my program, and more importantly my future career path.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: see above.
I wanted a better grasp of financial modeling as it relates to forest and ecosystem finance.
I took this course to better understand how private actors make decisions regarding timberland.
Curiosity. It seems like everyone should know something about finance.
I took this course because I have never taken a finance course before and having knowledge of forest finance is very important for someone aspiring to be a forest resource manager.
for the introduction to finance
To learn new skills.
It fulfilled a requirement for my degree, it also seemed to be a valuable topic for almost any field, and an applicable skill to have.
To gain a understanding of how environmental banking instruments are created and how these markets operate.
Highest reviews from fellow students of content and professor.
I was very interested to learn about ecosystem services mechanisms.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes! I got to think through risks and how to set up/walk through several financial models.
I think I have a better understanding than I did before the course.
Absolutely
Yes, I gained an introduction to financial analysis for natural resource management and learned the basics of building models in excel.
Yes very much.

not quite. I was hoping to gain a firmer, more thorough understanding of finance. but unfortunately, the finance lectures ended around early October. There was an exception exposure to forestry and ecostystem services, however.
Yes
Absolutely.

More or less? The course focused mainly on U.S. timber investments, I would have gained more from perhaps more broad examples of financing in other contexts as well, which is more where my interests lie (internationally)
Yes. I learned a lot from the lectures and assignments. I especially liked the assignments and found each one fundamental, challenging, and interesting.
Yes

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Spend most of your time on the assignments - ask Deborah and Jon for help outside of class on these assignments; pick their brains.
TAKE IT!

This course is especially useful for students who are looking for an exposure to conservation finance or would like to get more comfortable with basic accounting concepts as they relate to natural resources.

I would highly recommend them to take this course. I would also recommend them to develop a basic understanding of how finance works as this class usually has students not only from FES but also from SOM.
Worth taking!
Do the assignments before the deadline so you can ask the TA or Instructor for help.
Be comfortable with numbers and uncertainty.
Do it.
